name: Apply for a county parish holding (CPH) number

pages.title: Are you 18 or older?
You must be 18 or older to use this service

components.title: Html
components.content: To apply for a country parish holding (CPH) number, you must be 18 or older.

pages.title: Are you or your business already registered with the Rural Payments Agency?

components.title: Registered with the Rural Payments Agency

pages.title: Already registered with the Rural Payments Agency

components.title: Html
components.content:
You cannot use this form if you’re already registered on the Rural Payments service. The Rural Payments Agency (RPA) already has much of the information it needs to process your application. You must apply by phone instead.

Telephone (Defra rural services helpline): 03000 200 301
Monday to Friday, 8:30am to 5pm
Find out about call charges (opens in new tab)

pages.title: What country will you keep livestock in?

components.title: Country where you will keep livestock

pages.title: You cannot use this service

components.title: Html
components.content:
You cannot use this service to apply for a county parish holding (CPH) number if you live in Northern Ireland, Scotland or Wales.

Read guidance for:

  1. Northern Ireland (opens in new tab)
  2. Scotland (opens in new tab)
  3. Wales (opens in new tab)

pages.title: Arrival date

components.content:
Tell the Rural Payments Agency (RPA) when the livestock or animal by-products will arrive. This date must be no more than 6 weeks from today's date. If they will arrive later, do not apply for your CPH number now.

If you do not know when the livestock or animal by-products will arrive, give an estimate. If they have already arrived, you can put a date in the past.

RPA need to know this so they can prioritise your application.

components.title: What date will the livestock or animal by-products arrive?
components.hint: If you keep both livestock and animal by-products, tell us the date the first one will arrive

pages.title: The livestock must arrive within 6 weeks

components.title: Html
components.content:
The livestock or animal by-products must arrive within 6 weeks from today's date.

You cannot apply for your county parish number (CPH) number now as the date you have entered is more than 6 weeks from today's date.

You can return to fill in this form closer to the arrival date of your livestock or animal by-products.

pages.title: What livestock will you keep?
You must use a different service

components.title: Html
components.content:
Less than 50 poultry or other captive birds

If you’re a keeper of less than 50 poultry or other captive birds, you must register with the Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) (opens in new tab). This includes any birds you keep as pets.

APHA will provide you with a CPH number when you register. You should not apply for a country parish holding (CPH) number from the Rurual Payments Agency (RPA) using this form.

If you already have a CPH number from keeping other livestock, call the RPA to get your CPH number updated to include keeping 50 poultry or other captive birds.

Telephone (Defra rural services helpline): 03000 200 301
Monday to Friday, 8:30am to 5pm
Find out about call charges (opens in new tab)

components.title: Html
components.content:
Racing pigeons

There's a different process for racing pigeons.

Find out how to register a racing pigeon establishment to move pigeons to the EU or Northern Ireland for a race (opens in new tab).

pages.title: What do you use animal by-products for?

components.title: What you use animal by-products for
components.hint: For example, using animal by-products to produce pet food

pages.title: Business or hobbyist

components.title: Html
components.content:
When you apply for a country parish holding (CPH) number, the Rural Payments Agency (RPA) will give you a single business identifier (SBI) number. You'll get an SBI number even if you're not a business.

If you're a hobbyist keeper, RPA will use your full name as your business name.

components.title: Are you a hobbyist keeper or a business?

pages.title: What's the name of the applicant?

components.content: Enter the name of the person applying for the county parish holding (CPH) number. This should be the person who is responsible for the livestock.

pages.title: Business name

components.content: RPA needs to register you as a business on their system (the Rural Payments service) before they can give you a CPH number. They must do this even if you keep livestock as pets or for a hobby.

components.title: What is the name of the business?

pages.title: What's your name?
Telephone numbers

components.content: The Rural Payments Agency (RPA) will use the phone numbers you provide to contact you if they need to discuss your application.

pages.title: What's your email address?

components.title: Email address
components.hint: The Rural Payments Agency (RPA)  will email your CPH number to you.

pages.title: What's your business address?

components.title: Business address
components.hint: Your business address must be a postal address

pages.title: Is your business address the same as your home address?

components.title: Is your business address the same as your home address?

pages.title: What's your home address?
Legal status of your business

components.content:
The Rural Payments Agency (RPA) needs the legal status of your business to register you on the Rural Payments service.

Read more about registering a business (opens in new tab) or find out more about charity types (opens in new tab). If you're not sure, seek professional advice.

pages.title: Legal status of your business: something else

components.title: Html
components.content:
RPA needs the legal status of your business to register you on the Rural Payments service.

Read more about registering a business (opens in new tab) or find out more about charity types (opens in new tab). If you're not sure, seek professional advice.

pages.title: Companies House

components.title: Html
components.content:
The Rural Payments Agency (RPA) need to know your company number. You can get this from Companies House.

Find your company number (opens in new tab)

You can also find your company number on any documents you have received from Companies House.

components.title: What's your company number?
components.hint: You company number is either an 8-digit number or 2 letters followed by a 6-digit number, for example, 03256178 or SL123456.

pages.title: Charity number

components.content: Search the register of charities (opens in new tab) to find your charity number.

pages.title: What is the main purpose of your business?

components.title: Business type
components.hint: Select the main purpose of your business. If you're a farmer and you keep livestock, select 'farmer'.

pages.title: What is the main purpose of your business: something else?

components.title: Main purpose of your business: something else

pages.title: What type of business do you have?

components.title: What type of business do you have?

pages.title: Is your business a market, showground or zoo?

components.title: Is your business a market, showground or zoo?
components.hint: Your answer will help us to process your application correctly

pages.title: Does your business have a second contact?

components.title: Does your business have a second contact?

pages.title: Do you want to add a second contact?

components.title: Second contact
components.hint: For example, if someone else helps you keep the livestock or you want them to communicate with the Rural Payments Agency on your behalf. Secondary contacts can view and make changes to the information we hold

pages.title: Contact details of the second contact

components.title: Email address of second contact
components.hint: The email address of the second contact must be different from the main contact

components.title: Home address for the second contact

pages.title: What's the address where you'll keep livestock or use animal by-products?

components.title: Address for livestock and animal by-products
components.hint: This will help trace the animals to prevent and contain disease

pages.title: National Grid field number for where you'll keep livestock

components.content: RPA need the National Grid field number for the main area where you'll keep livestock. For example, if you're a:

components.title: National Grid field number for where you'll keep livestock

components.content:
If your business uses animal by-products, this will be for the premises where you use them.

Use the MAGIC map (opens in new tab) to find the National Grid field numbers for your land or buildings. Follow these instructions:

  1. Select ‘Get Started’.
  2. Search for a postcode or place.
  3. Using the map, locate the land or building. Use the +/- icons to zoom in and out.
  4. In the top toolbar, select the fourth icon along ('Where am I?') - it looks like a target.
  5. Click on the land or building.
  6. A pop-up box will appear showing the land details for this location. The National Grid field number is the fourth number down and comes after the ‘Grid Ref’ (Ordnance Survey grid reference). It’s made up of 2 letters and 8 numbers, for example, SO 0418 8589.

options.customValidationMessage: Enter a valid National Grid field number

components.title: What's the National Grid field number for the main area where you'll keep livestock or use animal by-products?

pages.title: Will you keep livestock or use animal by-products anywhere else?

components.hint: The Rural Payments Agency (RPA) needs to know about any other land or buildings you'll use to keep livestock
components.title: Will you keep livestock or use animal by-products anywhere else?

pages.title: National Grid field numbers for other land and buildings where you'll keep livestock

components.content:
Tell us where you'll keep animals, in addition to the main area.

Use the MAGIC map (opens in new tab) to find the National Grid field numbers for your land or buildings. Follow these instructions:

  1. Select ‘Get Started’.
  2. Search for a postcode or place.
  3. Using the map, locate the land or building. Use the +/- icons to zoom in and out.
  4. In the top toolbar, select the fourth icon along ('Where am I?') - it looks like a target.
  5. Click on the land or building.
  6. A pop-up box will appear showing the land details for this location. The National Grid field number is the fourth number down and comes after the ‘Grid Ref’ (Ordnance Survey grid reference). It’s made up of 2 letters and 8 numbers, for example, SO 0418 8589.

components.content:
Find out about the available funding for farmers, growers and land managers (opens in new tab)

Answering 'No' does not stop you from applying for funding at a later date.
